The Dallas Group of America, Inc. Texas City Facility produces a high-purity ammonium chloride crystal. Anhydrous ammonia is reacted with hydrochloric acid to produce an ammonium chloride solution. Because the concentration of hydrochloric acid used at the plant is less than 37 percent, the hydrochloric acid is exempt from RMP requirements.In a series of steps, the ammonium chloride solution is concentrated, refined,and reduced to a powder form. The finished product is bagged and sold commercially.



In the worst case scenario, an ammonia tank is predicted to rupture. The ruptured tank spills 62,040 pounds of ammonia into a diked area. The release rate of the ammonia is 6204 pounds per minute and the total spill is estimated to evaporate in 10 minutes. PSM-11 FLAME AND/OR ENTRY PERMIT OVERVIEW



A. Policy

A Flame and/or Entry Permit will be required for any job involving:

1. Entry into any confined area or tank in the plant.

2. Use of any flam

e or spark-producing device in a production area of the plant.

3. a. Opening any lines or equipment that contain hazardous materials.

b. This does not apply to equipment containing Ammonium Chloride Solutions, pump seals, valve packing etc.

c. The supervisor must decide whether a permit is needed or not.

B. General Procedure

1. The Plant Manager or Maintenance Supervisor will completely fill in the top part of the permit.

2. a. There are two check-off columns on the permit with appropriate approval signatures below each column

b. Plant Manager or Maintenance Supervisor will survey the job location and determine what precautions are required.

c. The supervisor will then check the left-hand column for required procedures and equipment and will arrange for the necessary preparations.

3. a. The permit will then be given to the appropriate operator.

b. As preparations are completed, the operator will check off each item in the right hand column.

c. When all items are complete per the supervisor preparation checklist, the operator will sign the permit and return it to the supervisor.

4. a. The supervisor will again survey the job site.

b. When fully satisfied that the required preparations are completed he/she will sign the permit and attach the tag copy at the job site.

C. Specific Procedures

1. Entry Procedure

A Flame and/or Entry Permit are required to entry into any confined space.

a. 1. All piping connected to equipment to be entered shall be isolated to prevent the entry of contaminates or hazardous materials while personnel are inside.

2. All chemical lines (either liquid or gas), all inert gas lines, and all steam lines shall be physically isolated by blanking of flanges or disconnecting of piping.

3. Where applicable and appropriate, equipment shall be cleaned, flushed, purged and ventilated.

b. The atmosphere in the vessel will be tested to ensure that flammable gas mixtures are not present, and the oxygen concentration is above 19.5%.

c. Th

e results of this test will be recorded on the permit.

d. Ventilation shall be adequate to provide safe breathing air and to remove excess heat.

e. A standby man will be continuously present outside the opening of the confined area when personnel are inside.

f. All personnel entering a confined area shall wear a safety harness with a lifeline extending to the standby man.

g. Rescue breathing apparatus must be on hand nearby the confined space.

h. 1. During plant emergencies, including fires, all personnel entry permits are canceled until all areas have been pronounced safe.

2. During the emergency, all personnel will exit and remain outside of the vessel or confined space.

2. Welding and Burning Procedure

a. 1. A Flame and/or Entry permit is required for any work utilizing a flame or spark-producing device in any production area.

2. A production area is defined as any area containing a process unit, storage facilities, process/product lines, etc. or in the vicinity thereof.

3. The maintenance shop and outlying areas are obviously excluded.

b.1. Before any work requiring a flame-producing device may be performed within a production area; an explosimeter check must be within a production area, an explosimeter check must be made to determine if the area is free from combustible gases.

2. The results of this test will be recorded on the permit.

c.1. In cases where cutting or burning operations are being carried out, the immediate area must be surveyed to ensure protection against fire.

2. Where necessary, tarps or screens must be used to protect against sparks or flashes.

d. An appropriate fire extinguisher will be available at the immediate job site.

e. 1. Combustible material must be removed from the work area, if possible.

2. If removal is not possible, such material must be covered with a screen or tarp.

f. Lines and equipment must be drained and flushed or purged by operating personnel and checked for flammable gases or liquids prior to welding or

burning on the equipment.

g. To prevent injury to other personnel in the unit, the area where sparks or hot projectiles may fall will be isolated using yellow barricade tape.

h.1. Appropriate welding goggles or hoods shall be used for all gas or electric welding or cutting.

2. Safety glasses must be worn under a welding hood.

i. For cutting or welding along or above a railroad right-of-way, a blue flag must be placed on the tracks if sparks or plugs could constitute a fire hazard to passing railroad cars.

j.1. Prior to beginning hot work in hazardous areas, the atmosphere must be checked for flammable gases.

2. The atmosphere must be re-checked if work has stopped for more than ? hour or if there is reason to believe changes have occurred.

3. Anhydrous Ammonia and Hydrochloric Acid Procedure

A flame and/or Entry Permit are required prior to breaking into any lines or equipment which have contained or can be expected to contain either Anhydrous Ammonia or Hydrochloric Acid.

a. The equipment will be emptied and flushed thoroughly with water, if possible.

b. If the job is routine and the equipment can be properly secured and flushed, personnel breaking into the equipment will wear full-face canister masks for vapors.

c. If the work is non-routine or the responsible supervisor determines that potential for the release of a significant quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia or Hydrochloric Acid

exists, additional precautions are required as follows:

1. Personnel breaking into the equipment will wear fresh air breathing equipment and appropriate protective clothing

2. a. Charged fire hoses will be laid at the job site and manned to disperse vapors in the event of a spill.

b. Sufficient respiratory protection and protective clothing will be available at the job site or all personnel at the site.

c. An operating supervisor must be present when the equipment is initially opened, and no valves will be operated at the site after work has begun except under his direct s

upervision.

d. For All Permits

1. Local hazards must be explained to parties involves in the work.

2. The locations and use of all safety equipment must be shown to all parties involved.
